## Relationship of quantitative and qualitative variables {background-color="#B5E2FF"}

```{r}
#| include: false
library(here)
library(ggplot2)
library(tidyverse)
df_dartpoints <- read.csv(here("lect/w02/data/dartpoints.csv"))
```

## Before we continue

Note that there are several ways of how to write `qqplot` code. Just keep in mind that you always need to specify the **data** you want to plot, the **aesthetic / mapping** (`aes()`) and **geometry** (`geom_`) and that you need to separate different layers by `+`
Here are same examples, all are leading to the same result:

```{r}
#| eval: false
ggplot(data = df_dartpoints, mapping = aes(x = Length))+
  geom_histogram()
```
::: fragment

```{r}
#| eval: false
ggplot(df_dartpoints, aes(x = Length))+
  geom_histogram()
```
:::
::: fragment
```{r}
#| eval: false
ggplot(df_dartpoints) +
  aes(x = Length) +
  geom_histogram()
```
:::
::: fragment
```{r}
#| eval: false
plot_1 <- ggplot(df_dartpoints)
plot_1 + aes(x = Length) + geom_histogram()
```
:::
::: fragment
```{r}
#| eval: false
df_dartpoints %>% ggplot() +
  aes(x = Length) +
  geom_histogram()
```

NOTE: `%>%` comes from `magrittr` package. We will talk about it later 
:::

## Relationship of two quantitative variables {background-color="#B5E2FF"}

## Correlation 

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width=60%}
::::: {.incremental}
- A statistic describing a relationship between two continuous variables.
- To what degree is a variable y explained by x?
- Correlation coefficient **r**, from **-1 to +1**.

- **Correlation does not imply causation!**

- r = 1 – strong positive correlation
- r = 0.5 – moderately strong positive correlation
- r = 0 – variables are not correlated
- r = -0.2 – weak negative correlation
- r = -1 – strong negative correlation
:::::
:::
::: {.column width=40%}
::::: {.fragment}
Function `cor()`

```{r}
cor(df_dartpoints$Length, df_dartpoints$Width)
cor(df_dartpoints$Length, df_dartpoints$Weight)
cor(df_dartpoints$Width, df_dartpoints$Thickness)
```
:::::
:::
::::

## Scatter plot 

- Plot displying **two continuous** variables, x and y.
- *x axis*: explanatory variable, independent, predictor.
- *y axis*: dependent variable, response.

```{r}
ggplot(df_dartpoints) +
  aes(x = Length, y = Weight) +
  geom_point()

```

## Correlation examples

```{r}
#| echo: false 
#| fig-height: 3
cor09 <- tibble::as_tibble(MASS::mvrnorm(50, mu = c(0,0), Sigma = matrix(c(1, 0.924, 0.924, 1), ncol = 2), empirical = TRUE))
cor05 <- tibble::as_tibble(MASS::mvrnorm(50, mu = c(0,0), Sigma = matrix(c(1, 0.56, 0.56, 1), ncol = 2), empirical = TRUE))
cor00 <- tibble::as_tibble(MASS::mvrnorm(50, mu = c(0,0), Sigma = matrix(c(1, 0.08, 0.08, 1), ncol = 2), empirical = TRUE))
cor06n <- tibble::as_tibble(MASS::mvrnorm(50, mu = c(0,0), Sigma = matrix(c(1, -0.62, -0.62, 1), ncol = 2), empirical = TRUE))

g09 <- ggplot(cor09, aes(V1, V2)) + 
  stat_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + geom_point() + 
  theme(axis.title = element_blank())

g05 <- ggplot(cor05, aes(V1, V2)) + 
  stat_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + geom_point() + 
  theme(axis.title = element_blank())
  
g00 <- ggplot(cor00, aes(V1, V2)) + 
  stat_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + geom_point() + 
  theme(axis.title = element_blank())
  
g06n <- ggplot(cor06n, aes(V1, V2)) + 
  stat_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + geom_point() + 
  theme(axis.title = element_blank())

gridExtra::grid.arrange(g09, g05, g00, g06n, nrow = 1)
```

## Correlation examples  {auto-animate=true}

```{r}
#| echo: false 
#| fig-height: 3
g09 <- g09 + labs(title = "r = 0.924")
g05 <- g05 + labs(title = "r = 0.560")
g00 <- g00 + labs(title = "r = 0.080")
g06n <- g06n + labs(title = "r = -0.620")

gridExtra::grid.arrange(g09, g05, g00, g06n, nrow = 1)
```

## Scatter plots 
We already know scatterplot from the last part:
```{r}
ggplot(data = df_dartpoints) +
  aes(x = Weight, y = Length) + 
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.5, color = "steelblue") +
  labs(x = "Weight (g)", y = "Length (mm)",
       title = "Relationship of weight and length of dart points") +
  theme_light()
```



## Scatter plots {auto-animate=true}
- let's use `geom_smooth()` to better see the trend that the points are forming
```{r}
ggplot(data = df_dartpoints) +
  aes(x = Weight, y = Length) + 
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.5, color = "steelblue") +
  geom_smooth()+
  labs(x = "Weight (g)", y = "Length (mm)",
       title = "Relationship of weight and length of dart points") +
  theme_light()
```

## Scatter plots {auto-animate=true}
- by `method = "lm"` you can plot the linear model
- `se = FALSE` will turn off the confidence band

```{r}
ggplot(data = df_dartpoints) +
  aes(x = Weight, y = Length) + 
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.5, color = "steelblue") +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE)+
  labs(x = "Weight (g)", y = "Length (mm)",
       title = "Relationship of weight and length of dart points") +
  theme_light()
```

## Scatterplots
- let's add another layer and change the `theme_`:

```{r}
ggplot(data = df_dartpoints) +
  aes(x = Weight, y = Length) + 
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.5, color = "steelblue") +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE)+
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 40, by = 5))+
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 120, by = 10))+
  labs(x = "Weight (g)", y = "Length (mm)",
       title = "Relationship of weight and length of dart points") +
  theme_linedraw()

```


## Small multiples 

```{r}
ggplot(data = df_dartpoints) +
  aes(x = Weight, y = Length) + 
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.5, color = "steelblue") +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE)+
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 40, by = 5))+
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 120, by = 10))+
  labs(x = "Weight (g)", y = "Length (mm)",
       title = "Relationship of weight and length of dart points") +
  theme_linedraw()+
  facet_wrap(~Name)
```
